fields.charwording2: Whether the zygomatic arch is present or absent
fields.notes: Whether the zygomatic arch is present or absent. The zygomatic arch is a bony bridge at the side of the skull. It is present in most mammals but absent in shrews.

fields.charwording2: Whether a diastema exists between any of the teeth
fields.notes: Whether a diastema exists between any of the teeth. A diastema is a large space between teeth. Rodents generally have a large diastema between the incisors and the first molar. This feature can be seen on both upper and lower toothrows.

fields.charwording2: The number of upper molars in half the upper jaw (maxilla).
fields.notes: The number of upper molars in half the upper jaw (maxilla). A count of teeth starting from the middle (mid-sagital plane) and counting back (distally) along the toothrow, i.e. half the total number of upper teeth. Rogers node 11

fields.charwording2: The number of lower molars in half the lower jaw (mandible).
fields.notes: The number of lower molars in half the lower jaw (mandible). A count of teeth starting from the middle (mid-sagital plane) and continuing back (distally) along the toothrow, i.e. half the total number of lower teeth. Rogers node 11

fields.charwording: whether alveolar simple complex (Arvicanthine) or simple (Mus)
fields.charwording2: The alveoli of rodents are arranged in either a complex pattern as in Arvicanthis (with 4 or more sockets for LM1 and 5 or more for UM1) or simple pattern as in Mus (typically 2 sockets for LM1 and 3 for UM1).
fields.notes: The alveoli of rodents are arranged in either a complex pattern as in Arvicanthis (with 4 or more sockets for LM1 and 5 or more for UM1) or simple pattern as in Mus (typically 2 sockets for LM1 and 3 for UM1). See Davis (1965). Replaced by two characters: Number of UM1 medial roots, and Number of LM1 medial roots

fields.charwording2: Whether the skull is covered in small, palpable dimples (like a golf ball).
fields.notes: Whether the skull is covered in small, palpable dimples (like a golf ball). Rogers node 12.

fields.charwording2: Whether the labial surface of the incisors have longitudinal grooves running the length of the tooth, and how many such grooves are present.
fields.notes: Whether the labial surface of the incisors have longitudinal grooves running the length of the tooth, and how many such grooves are present. Rogers nodes 2 and 18.

fields.charwording2: When viewed from the front (anterior perspective) whether the biting (occlusal) edge of the incisors come to a point or are flat and thus chisel shaped.
fields.notes: When viewed from the front (anterior perspective) whether the biting (occlusal) edge of the incisors come to a point or are flat and thus chisel shaped.

fields.charwording2: Whether the incisors project forware (proodont), vertically (orthodont) or backwards (opisthodont)
fields.notes: This trait should be evaluated from the side (lateral perspective). If the incisors project forward they are  proodont, if they project straight up and down then orthodont, and if they extend backwards they are opisthodont.

fields.charwording2: Upper molars have transverse ridges or plates (laminae) and no indication of cusps except in unworn specimens.
fields.notes: Applies to rodents. Upper molars have transverse ridges or plates (laminae) and no indication of cusps except in unworn specimens. Many rodents have cusps that merge together as they wear forming lophs. These are different from the laminae described here.

fields.charwording: upper molar rows parallel or converging
fields.charwording2: Whether the molars rows are parallel or converge toward the front of the skull.
fields.notes: Whether the molars rows are parallel or converge toward the front of the skull. Rogers node 5, 26

fields.charwording: number of major roots under UM1
fields.charwording2: A count of the number of roots sockets in the UM1 alveolus.
fields.notes: A count of the number of roots sockets in the UM1 alveolus.
A count of the number of sockets in the UM2 alveolus.
A count of the number of sockets in the UM3 alveolus.

fields.charwording2: whether the maxilla has a prominant incisive foramen
fields.notes: Whether there are lengthy opennings in the palate. These should be scored as present if the openning are individually greater than the length of the UM1.

fields.charwording2: whether the anterior incisive foramen extends to or past UM1
fields.notes: The extent of the anterior incisive foramen (a.i.f.). This trait scores whether or not the a.i.f. extends past the beginning of the UM1, specifically, past the UM1 alveolus. Rogers node 34, 37, 39.

fields.charwording2: The degree of post orbital development.
fields.notes: The post orbital projection is a flange of bone originating from the skull roof. If the flange communicates with the zygomatic arch it forms a post orbital bar, and if the space behind the orbit is walled off it forms post orbital closure. Rogers node 7.
The base of the zygomatic arch forms a flat plate where it originates off the zygomatic (jugal) bone. Found in  most rodents.

fields.charwording2: Whether the zygomatic plate is tall or short.
fields.notes: A tall zygomatic plate has an anterior margin that reaches from its root on the maxilla all the way up to the origin of the zygomatic arch. A short plate curves posteriorly and then superiorly again forming an S shape. Rogers node 29

fields.charwording2: Whether the anterior margin of the zygomatic plate is concave, straight or convex
fields.notes: The front (anterior) margin of the zygomatic plate rises vertically from its origin at the maxilla. This forward edge is slighly convex or straight, flat to slightly concave or strongly concave. Rogers nodes 34, 36, 40.
The relative bredth of the widest part of the infraorbital foramen as compared the the width of the first molar when viewed from the front (anterior) perspective. Rogers node 7.

fields.charwording2: Whether there is a protrusion of bone just anterior to the maxillary toothrow.
fields.notes: The presence of a protusion of bone anchoring the masseter muscles on the maxilla just before (anterior) to the toothrow and near the root  of the zygomatic arch.

fields.charwording2: Whether there is a maxillary flange projecting laterally from the maxilla just anterior to UM1.
fields.notes: Flange of bone project lateerally from the maxilla between the anterior incisive foramen and the UM1. Rogers node 10.

fields.charwording2: The relative size of the upper molars, especially the UM3.
fields.notes: The relative length of the upper molars. Rogers node 15

fields.charwording: Size of UM3 relative to UM2
fields.charwording2: The relative size of the upper second and third molars
fields.notes: The relative length of the upper second and third molars. Rogers node 18.

fields.charwording2: Development of the antero-lingual cusp (t1)
fields.notes: Applies to rodents. The t1 is present as a distinct csup. It may be shifted far posteriorly, as in Mus, or absent alltogether as in dendromurines. Rogers node 17.

fields.charwording2: The relative size of the anterio-medial cusp on the first molar.
fields.notes: Applies to rodents. The relative size (maximum basal diameter) of antero-lingual (t1) and antero-buccal (t3) cusps

fields.charwording2: Development of the disto-lingual cusp (t7) on the first upper molar.
fields.notes: Applies to rodents. Whether there exists a cusp in the disto-lingual portion of the upper M1.

fields.charwording2: Development of the (t9) bucco-distal cusp on the first upper molar.
fields.notes: Applies to rodents. Whether there exists a cusp in the bucco-distal portion of the upper M1. CS1: small cusp or crest deleted.

fields.charwording2: whether the t1 on the upper first molar has a short crest extending distally or is instead rounded on this aspect.
fields.notes: Applies to rodents. The antero-lingual cusp (t1) on the upper first molar has a crest or ridge extending off its distal (posterior) margin. The ridge gives the effect that the t1 is flattened and often there is a concavity on the side of the tooth as a result of the crest.

fields.charwording: UM1 t4 distal crest connecting to t8 or t7
fields.charwording2: UM1 t4 distal crest connecting to t8 or t7
fields.notes: Applies to rodents. The medio- and postero- cusps on the lingual side (t4 and (t8 or t7) of the UM1 are linked by a crest

fields.charwording2: The medio- and postero- cusps on the buccal (cheek)  side of the UM1 are linked by a crest
fields.notes: Applies to rodents. The medio- and postero- cusps on the buccal (cheek)  side of the UM1 are linked by a crest
Applies to rodents. The bucco-distal cusp (t9) on the UM1 is lateral (buccal) to the cusp just above (anterior) to it, the t6.

fields.charwording2: The presence of a shelf or crest along the disto-buccal (posterior, external) margin of the upper first molar
fields.notes: Applies to rodents. The posterior cingulum is a crest at the outside, back (bucco-distal) corner of the tooth. If it is present it is distinct from the t9 cusp and separated from it by a pit (fovea). Alternatively the t8 and t9 cusps may be joined by a single large crest with no separate posterior cingulum present. In this case the back of the tooth forms one convex surface. As a variant the posterior cingulum may be absent and the back of the tooth may have an indentation where the posterior cingulum would be.

fields.charwording2: whether the upper second molar hasa mesio-buccal cusp
fields.notes: Applies to rodents. Whether the mesio-buccal (antero-labial) cusp (t3) is present on the upper M2.

fields.charwording2: whether the large lingual cusp on the upper third molar is elongated antero-posteriorly
fields.notes: Applies to rodents. Whether the medio-lingual cusp (t4) on the upper M3 is elongate such that it its mesio-distal length along its base is more than 1.5x that of the t1 on the upper M3. This is a characteristic of Mylomys and Golunda.

fields.charwording2: The position of the posterior incisive foramina
fields.notes: Applies to rodents. The posterior incisive foramina are the back (posterior) pair of openning in the pallate they vary in size and this character notes the forward (anterior) most position of the foramen. In some specimens the openning is sloped and thus multiple

fields.charwording: posterior extent of the bony palate
fields.charwording2: whether the bony palate extend posteriorly far beyond the tooth row.
fields.notes: The position of the distal margin of the bony palate relative to the posterior margin of the tooth row.

fields.charwording2: the shape of the posterior margin of the bony palate that forms the opening to the choanae
fields.notes: The shape of the posterior margin of the bony palate.
Minimum linear distance between the orbits

fields.charwording2: width of the inter-pteregoid relative to the width of the last upper molar
fields.notes: Size of the interpteregoid space in relation to lower  M3
maximum linear distance between the pteregoid plates in mm.
maximum linear mesio-distal tooth dimension in mm
The measure of the outside angle (anterior) between the slope of the mesial surface of the t3 cusp and the slope of the UM1 anterior tooth root up to the cingulum.

fields.charname: incisor to anterior incisive foramen distance
fields.notes: linear distnace from the lingual edge of the central incisor back to the anterior margin of the anterior incisive foramen
negative numbers indicate anterior incisive foramen extends distal to UM1
Minimum distance between the infraorbital foraina.

Each tooth is held in place by tooth roots. The holes in the jaw for the roots are called the alveoli (singular alveolus). This character is a count of the number of holes for the roots of the first tooth in the back of the lower jaw (molar = LM1).

Each tooth is held in place by tooth roots. The holes in the jaw for the roots are called the alveoli (singular alveolus). This character is a count of the number of holes for the roots of the second tooth in the back of the lower jaw (molar = LM2).

Each tooth is held in place by tooth roots. The holes in the jaw for the roots are called the alveoli (singular alveolus). This character is a count of the number of holes for the roots of the third tooth in the back of the lower jaw (molar = LM3).

fields.charwording2: presence of an antero-buccal cusp on the lower first molar.
fields.notes: Whether there is a cusp in the antero-buccal position of the lower M1. Disabled character due to difficulty in differentiating CS1 from CS2. Character needs to be redefined.

fields.charwording2: presence of a cusplet between the antero-buccal (tE) and antero-lingual (tF) cusps
fields.notes: Whether there is a cusplet between the antero-buccal and antero-lingual cusps of the lower M1.

fields.charwording2: presence and form of the anter-buccal cusplet on the lower first molar.
fields.notes: Whether there is a cusplet between the antero-buccal cusp and protoconid on the lower M1.

fields.charwording2: development of the small cusplet along the buccal margin of the tooth between the protoconid (tC) and hypoconid (tA) on the lower first molar
fields.notes: Whether there is a buccal cusplet between the protoconid and hypoconid on the lower M1.

fields.charwording2: development of a cusp or shelf along the distal margin of the first lower molar.
fields.notes: Whether there is a posterior cinculum adorning the lower M1

fields.charwording2: Whether there is an antero-buccal cusp present on the lower second molar.
fields.notes: Whether there is an antero-buccal cusp present on the lower M2.

fields.charwording2: Whether there is a buccal cusplet between the protoconid and hypoconid on the lower second molar.
fields.notes: Whether there is a buccal cusplet between the protoconid and hypoconid on the lower M2.

fields.charwording2: development of a cusp of shelf along the distal margin o fthe lower second molar
fields.notes: Whether there is a posterior cingulum adorning the lower M2.
The position of the mental formen on the mandible relative to the superior surface of the corpus at the diastema.

Whether the posterior portion of the incisor, forms a bulge on the buccal surface of the mandibular corpus. Three grades are recognized, with the division between 1 and 2 set at whether the protrusion forms a flange that curves back superiorly forming a groove.

fields.charwording2: Whether UM1 has 1 or two lingual roots
fields.notes: Whether the upper first molar has one or two medial roots

fields.charwording2: Whether LM1 has two or more than two lingual roots
fields.notes: Whether the lower first molar has two or more than two roots visible from the medial aspect.

fields.charwording2: presence of t3 cusp on upper third molar
fields.notes: Whether the antero-buccal cusp (t3) is present on the upper third molar.  This character is significant for the diagnosis of Acomys, which have a well developed M3-t3 along with an absent or weakly developed M3-t1. See papers by C. Denys (1990; 1994). Could expand this character to have three characters states, absent, t3 present but smaller than M2-t3, t3 present and larger than M2-t3.

fields.charwording: LM1 with crest connecting tC to CE
fields.charwording2: Whether the lower first molar has a crest connecting the middle lobe to the anterior lobe on the buccal (cheek) side.
fields.notes: For lm1, whether there is a connection between the middle lobe to the anterior lobe and if so, whether the connection is more buccal (tC-tE),more lingual(tD-tF) or central (in the midline).

fields.charwording: whether the upper M3 has a t1 (antero-lingual) cusp
fields.charwording2: Whether the upper third molar has a t1 (antero-lingual) cusp present.
fields.notes: Whether the upper third molar has a t1 (antero-lingual) cusp present. Denys 1990, 1994, Barome

fields.charwording2: Whether the prelobe cusps form an acute or obtuse angle anteriorly.
fields.notes: for lm1, whether the angle formed between tE and tF is acute(<= 90 degrees), obtuse (> 90 degrees) or linear(approx 180 degrees).
